Louisiana is reopening the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) program for families who did not apply in May and June. Families of children who receive free or reduced-price school meals may be eligible to receive financial benefits for meals missed in 2019-2020 when schools closed due to the pandemic. Apply from September 8 at 8 a.m. to September 29 at 5 p.m. These one-time benefits total $285 per child of families who were eligible for free and reduced-price meals during the entire closure last spring. Parents who started receiving free and reduced-price school meals in May will receive $91.20 per eligible child. The online application is simple. The information submitted must exactly match the information on file with the school system in order for the application to successfully submit. #louisianabelieves

https://pebt.doe.louisiana.gov/PublicApps/SNP/

"Louisiana may not be the largest state in the union but we have a big table for collaboration. I look forward to bringing people together to collectively move our state forward. shared_text:
Wanda Porter Johnson
April 20 at 9:09 PM ·

Third grader (now 4thgrader) interviews State Representative! Thanks Louisiana State Representative, Marcus Bryant for sharing your job, what you do, and how at a young age you can represent your State! Dailee's teacher gave them a project two weeks ago on learning about the three branches of government. Through our discussion, I went on to teach her about City officials and who they are, Parish officials and who they are, School Board Officials and who they are, and State officials and who they are. To help relate studies with real life, I contacted Representative Bryant and he was kind to allow her to interview him. She researched some things in her community she would like to see changed and Rep Bryant made note of her concerns. It is such a blessing to have elected officials to take time out to help educate kids with the power of how Government works!
#alwaysfindingwaystolearn
#learningatHOME
#LaEducation
#LouisianaLearns
#LouisianaAdapts

We surveyed all public school systems on continuous education opportunities. Among the key takeaways:

*More school systems are offering continuous education now than one month ago.

*Louisiana must continue the use of curricular materials typically utilized in the classroom.

*The frequency at which students engage with teachers and receive feedback on their work may need to increase.

*Many students and teachers do not have the right technology to maximize learning.

*Expanded learning time may be necessary to accommodate lost time this year, as well as in anticipation of possible facility closures in the future.

*School systems need more support to expand technology access for students, serve students with disabilities, and provide professional development to teachers.

Governor John Bel Edwards
March 13 at 1:07 PM ·

Today, I signed a proclamation that immediately halts any gathering of more than 250 people until Monday, April 13, closes all K-12 public schools statewide effective Monday, March 16 and also moves upcoming state elections.

We are at an inflection point now and we are going to take bold action to minimize the further spread of this illness. That is why I am issuing this order today, ending all events of more than 250 people, closing our schools, and reducing the amount of face-to-face public interaction at state government buildings.

In a separate executive order I will grant Secretary of State Kyle Ardoin’s request to move our upcoming elections for April and May to June and July. The limits on gatherings of 250 people or more statewide is based on federal CDC guidance given the community spread which we are currently experiencing. These steps are necessary to protect the health and safety of the people of Louisiana from the risk of COVID-19.

📰: https://gov.louisiana.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/2403

post_text:
Two more great stops in the books!

We started our day at Peabody Magnet High School's on-site child care center. In its first year, the Pre-K classroom serves as a training lab for local high school students who are working toward their ancillary certificate in early childhood education. It was powerful to witness strong learning at all levels.

We then visited Munchkinland Child Development Centers, LLC, a "High Proficient" center serving children from 4 weeks to 4 years old. We observed the strong interactions among teachers and students, and we embraced learning through play.

Thank you to the Rapides Parish School Board and Rapides Early Childhood Education Network for your dedication to high quality early learning and to Rep. Ed Larvadain III, BESE Member Tony Davis and BESE Member Holly Boffy for joining us!
